docs.lead_paragraph: A Presidential advisory commission heard sharply conflicting testimony today about whether more Government regulation was needed to define and protect the rights of health care consumers. At its first meeting, at a hotel here, the panel began writing a bill of rights for patients as requested by President Clinton. Today's discussion was cordial, but the lines of future battles could be discerned.

headline.main: Panel Meets To Consider Bill of Rights For Patients

docs.abstract: Consumer Action aide Cathy L Hurwitz tells advisory panel writing patients' bill of rights for Pres Clinton that policy must be legally enforceable and hold health maintenance organizations and other health plans accountable; several panel members agree; other witnesses oppose more Government regulation; Secs Donna E Shalala and Alexis M Herman head panel, which includes doctors, labor leaders, HMO aides and state insurance commissioner (M)
docs.snippet: A Presidential advisory commission heard sharply conflicting testimony today about whether more Government regulation was needed to define and protect the rights of health care consumers.    At its first meeting, at a hotel here, the panel began...

docs.lead_paragraph: Diana Goodrich, 33, has had a hard time finding a steady job since a decade ago, when the nursing home where she worked closed. She had been getting along on temporary jobs and food stamps until she came up against a provision in the new Federal welfare law restricting adults without children at home to just three months of food stamps every three years. But the law also offers people like Ms. Goodrich a way out: She could keep the benefits if she did ''community service.'' So she became a part-time sorter of second-hand clothes at a Salvation Army warehouse here.

headline.main: Jobs, but Few New Skills, for Those on Welfare

docs.abstract: Federal officials are highly optimistic that community service can steer welfare recipients with few skills and little work experience into jobs, which is main objective of new 1996 welfare legislation; advocates of approach say community service imparts sense of what it is like to hold job; at least 10,000 welfare recipients already hold such jobs because many states, such as Ohio, established community service programs well before new welfare law was passed; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Christine Barbara Lubiak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Lubiak of Bridgewater Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Robert Leahy, the son of Dr. Mary Leahy and Dr. Robert Leahy of Olympia, Wash. The Rev. John D. Savard officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Mrs. Leahy, 34, was until last month an account executive at Exhibitgroup/Giltspur Inc., an exhibit services agency in Avon, Mass. She graduated from James Madison University. Her father, who is retired, was a vice president in the retail banking sector of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York. Her mother is an executive secretary to the director of operations at the New Brunswick Scientific Company in Edison, N.J.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sally Eran Park, a daughter of Kumok and Jae Chun Park of Overland Park, Kan., was married yesterday to Eugene Lee, a son of Sun Whi and Jae Won Lee of East Northport, N.Y. The Rev. Janet H. Legro, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The couple are graduates of Harvard, from which the bride also received a law degree.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration has blocked a plan that would give businesses a significant new role in administering social-service programs in Texas, aligning the White House with unions and against companies' seeking profits from the privatization of such programs nationwide. But Gov. George W. Bush of Texas says the state may proceed anyway with several aspects of his plan, under which private companies would interview applicants for $8 billion in benefits and help determine their eligibility.

headline.main: CLINTON REINING IN ROLE FOR BUSINESS IN WELFARE EFFORT

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration has blocked plan that would give businesses signficant new role in administering social-service programs in Texas, aligning White House with labor unions and against companies seeking profits from privatization of such programs nationwide; Gov George W Bush says state may proceed anyway with several aspects of his plan, under which private companies would interview applicants for $8 billion in benefits and help determine their eligibility (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For years after discovering he had AIDS, Mathew Kleiner refused to blame anyone for his illness, even the makers of the product that almost certainly infected him: a blood-clotting agent known as factor. Particularly not the makers of factor. After all, this clotting protein distilled from other people's blood plasma had helped Mr. Kleiner and thousands of other hemophiliacs live some semblance of normal lives, coagulating their blood when the bumps and bruises of everyday life might otherwise have sent them rushing to the hospital. It was as close to being a miracle drug as they ever expected to see.

headline.main: Hemophiliacs Organizing to Sue Over Blood-Clotting Product

docs.abstract: New York State bill to give hemophiliacs infected with virus that causes AIDS two years to sue makers of contaminated blood-clotting agents is subject of intense lobbying struggle and remains stalled in Senate; bill is intended to aid those who did not sue withing three-year limit after learning of infection because they did not then think manufacturers were at fault; groups and lawyers representing hemophiliacs say new evidence shows drug companies did not use adequate precautions during early 1980s; photos (M)
docs.snippet: For years after discovering he had AIDS, Mathew Kleiner refused to blame anyone for his illness, even the makers of the product that almost certainly infected him: a blood-clotting agent known as factor. Particularly not the makers of factor.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: MOTORISTS in West Palm Beach, Fla., were recently confronted by a billboard 100 yards from the Wellington Regional Medical Center. ''Why Stop Here?'' it asked. The sign advertised a nearby rival, the Columbia Palms West Hospital, owned by the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation. The billboard was a literal sign of the times from Columbia, the world's largest health care company.

headline.main: A Hospital Chain's Brass Knuckles, and the Backlash
headline.kicker: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT -- When Hospitals Play Hardball

docs.abstract: Article on Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, world's largest health care company; says chief executive Richard L Scott has built company with policy of aggressively acquiring hospitals, strictly controlling costs and fiercely competing with established rivals, many of which are not-for-profit operations; holds company's formula has helped it grow in a decade from nothing to $20 billion in revenues, with roughly 350 hospitals, 550 home-health-care offices and scores of other medical businesses in 38 states; opposition to Columbia's bare-knuckled competitive tactics and several Federal inquiries into its financial practices detailed; tables; photos (L)

byline.original: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB and KURT EICHENWALD

docs.lead_paragraph: Sunshine, a scarce commodity through the long upstate winter, has returned, bearing hope. Nature bursts with promise. Mike McConnell is unmoved.

headline.main: As U.S. Economy Races Along, Upstate New York Is Sputtering

docs.abstract: Much of upstate New York's economy barely budged in four years since recession of late 1980's and early 1990's ended in Northeast; growing national economy has lured away skilled residents and young people from region; upstate New York's already tepid expansion in employment stalled completely in 1996, even as pace accelerated in New York City and elsewhere; region's plight has been made all more glaring by reversal of fortunes within state; New York City, long derided by upstaters for its economic decline, has become state's economic leader; graphs compare economic plight of Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Utica; map (M)
docs.snippet: Sunshine, a scarce commodity through the long upstate winter, has returned, bearing hope. Nature bursts with promise.    Mike McConnell is unmoved.

docs.lead_paragraph: Was there, in fact, a budget agreement between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans, and what precisely did it contain? Those questions have reverberated around Capitol Hill this week as one problem after another has hampered the process of translating the oral agreement into writing. The accord was announced by Mr. Clinton and jubilant Republicans just seven days ago, on May 2.
docs.abstract: News analysis of partisan bickering that has broken out over exact meaning of Pres Clinton's balanced-budget agreement with Congressional Republicans; photo; Democrats charge Republicans with reneging, while Republicans say Clinton is trying to stuff his entire domestic agenda into pact; both sides, in their eagerness to announce a deal, clearly made announcement before critical loose ends were tied up; Sen Frank Lautenberg says he thought two sides had 'verbal handshakes' and was stunned at extent of misunderstanding; fears whole deal will unravel unless problems are resolved soon; White House officials want Republican-led appropriations and tax-writing committees to put details of projected spending and taxes for next five years in writing (M)
